pt: {sc}excessive{/sc} {sc}immoderate{/sc} {sc}inordinate{/sc} {sc}extravagant{/sc} {sc}exorbitant{/sc} {sc}extreme{/sc} mean going beyond a normal limit. {sc}excessive{/sc} implies an amount or degree too great to be reasonable or acceptable.
{sc}immoderate{/sc} implies lack of desirable or necessary restraint.
{sc}inordinate{/sc} implies an exceeding of the limits dictated by reason or good judgment.
{sc}extravagant{/sc} implies an indifference to restraints imposed by truth, prudence, or good taste.
{sc}exorbitant{/sc} implies a departure from accepted standards regarding amount or degree.
{sc}extreme{/sc} may imply an approach to the farthest limit possible or conceivable but commonly means only to a notably high degree.

et: Middle English {it}immoderat{/it}, from Latin {it}immoderatus{/it}, from {it}in-{/it} + {it}moderatus{/it}, past participle of {it}moderare{/it} to moderate
shortdef: exceeding just, usual, or suitable bounds
